Hi Martin,

*"It also means that the very same network region can show diff=
erent
behavior depending on the input it receives (e.g. visual cortices can=
 be
involved in auditory task when no retinal input drives the system). For=

computational studies this means, we should seek for networks that are abl=
e
to adapt to different types of input."*

Yes! I'm fascinated by this abil=
ity of brain regions to meaningfully
process whatever input types they are =
presented with, it seems quite
incredible, and I think points to something =
fundamental about how (at least
some regions of) natural neural networks op=
erate. On a side note, one of
the most amusing stories about this phenomena=
 is researchers placing an
electrode array on the tongue of a blind person =
and connecting the array to
a camera, and the blind person can learn to see=
 via the stimulus provided
to their tongue! The blind person doesn't just w=
ork out which stimulus
corresponds to an obstacle, etc, it actually feels l=
ike sight (albeit at a
very low resolution)...

Can you provide some links =
to publications or other information about the
"Brain in a box" model and t=
he related CPPN encoding?

Yes, I meant like in c. elegans. :) Couldn't thi=
nk of the name of it, I
think I read about it in the connectome book by Seb=
astian Seung.

There's a "Software" tab at the top of the website, I should=
 have been more
specific, sorry. Direct link: http://ojcoleman.com/content/=
software

I'm also planning on using the Izhikevich neuron model (so comput=
ationally
fast with such rich and apparently realistic dynamics!). I was pl=
anning on
trying out some model of synaptogenesis but haven't yet got aroun=
d to
looking at models; I'd be interested in learning more about your model=
 (and
why you're using that particular model). What is the "projection kern=
el"?
What prompted you to look at synaptogenesis?

Are you looking for task=
s/problems/environments to try your model on, or
are you just not sure how =
to set up a fitness function for a task you've
decided on?

Cheers,
Oliver
=








T: 0421 972 953 | E: oliver.coleman@... | W: http://ojcoleman=
.com



On 15 March 2013 19:59, martin_pyka <martin.pyka@...> wrote:
=

> **
>
>
> Hi Oliver,
>
> thanks for your response. I also think that self=
-organizing principles are
> an important factor in the development of neur=
al networks. I think, these
> mechanisms are one reason, why the evolution =
of neural networks is so
> robust. However, with the link to the polychroni=
zation article I wanted to
> highlight that heterogeneous conduction delays=
 might point to a new way of
> processing information / implementing certai=
n functions and that pattern
> generating encodings might be a very good wa=
y of making use of
> heterogeneous conduction delays.
>
> Here are some tho=
ughts to some of your statements:
>
>
> > What seems
> > more important is =
the interplay of these properties of different types of
> > neurons and syn=
apses that allows the network to self-organise in such a
> way
> > that it =
performs the required functions. The self-organisation creates
> the
> > de=
tailed form and function of the brain (eg topology and connection
> > stren=
gths).
>
> I agree with you. It also means that the very same network regio=
n can show
> different behavior depending on the input it receives (e.g. vi=
sual cortices
> can be involved in auditory task when no retinal input driv=
es the system).
> For computational studies this means, we should seek for =
networks that are
> able to adapt to different types of input.
>
>
> > It s=
eems more like natural genomes encode the neuron and
> > synapse types, and=
 which regions of the brain they go in, and the
> > properties of these neu=
ron and synapse types.
>
> That's why I developed the "Brain in a box" mode=
l, a naive approach, in
> which a CPPN just encodes the position and orient=
ation of dendritic and
> axonal projection cones. Intersections of cones le=
ad to connections between
> neurons. But there are better ways to implement=
 this.
>
>
> >I suspect there are still
> > some regions where the genome e=
ncodes, one way or another, a fairly
> precise
> > topology (though even in=
 this case the genome could make use of how the
> > neurons and synapses se=
lf-organise).
>
> you mean, like in c. elegans, which has exactly 302 neuro=
ns.!? I am
> wondering, whether it is correct to say that in simpler organi=
sms natural
> encodings tend to encode the precise topology whereas with in=
creasing
> complexity the encoding leaves more organizational tasks to self=
-organizing
> mechanisms.
>
>
> >
> > As part of my current work I'm planni=
ng on reproducing many of these
> > properties, including synaptic transmis=
sion delays, in a neural network
> > model to see how they affect the evolv=
ability and capabilities of evolved
> > networks performing online learning=
. I'm planning on using HyperNEAT or a
> > variant like ES-HyperNEAT, and a=
m in the middle of implementing these
> kinds
> > of properties in a neural=
 network model and creating a flexible HyperNEAT
> > set-up to allow specif=
ying the parameters for models of these properties.
> > The motivation bein=
g that a lot of these properties have been implicated
> in
> > learning pro=
cesses in the brain. See http://ojcoleman.com/node/1 and
> > http://ojcolem=
an.com/node/3 for details and links to the software. ;)
>
> Thanks for the =
links (btw: I commented in your third posting ;)). But I
> did not find any=
 link to the software you use? Do you work in Matlab,
> Python or something=
 else?
>
> With a colleague, we work on a model that implements structural
=
> plasticity, heterogeneous conduction delays and STDP in spiking neurons (=
we
> use the Izhikevich neuron and everything is implemented in Matlab).
> =
Synapses are build depending on the activation level of the neuron and its
=
> projection kernel. I think, the projection kernel could be something that=

> can be encoded by a CPPN. Having this kind of super-gun, we are now faci=
ng
> the question: how to setup an appropriate fitness-function, which runs=
 a
> bit into the discussions we had here the last weeks. :-)
>
> Best,
> M=
artin
>
>  
>

--f46d04428eb6ddd98204d82fdbec

<div style>

    <div>
      
      
=
      <p>Hi Oliver,<br>
<br>
thanks for your response. I also think that se=
lf-organizing principles are an important factor in the development of neur=
al networks. I think, these mechanisms are one reason, why the evolution of=
 neural networks is so robust. However, with the link to the polychronizati=
on article I wanted to highlight that heterogeneous conduction delays might=
 point to a new way of processing information / implementing certain functi=
ons and that pattern generating encodings might be a very good way of makin=
g use of heterogeneous conduction delays.<br>

<br>
Here are some thoughts =
to some of your statements:</p><div class=3D"im"><br>
<br>
> What seems<=
br>
> more important is the interplay of these properties of different t=
ypes of<br>
> neurons and synapses that allows the network to self-organ=
ise in such a way<br>
> that it performs the required functions. The sel=
f-organisation creates the<br>
> detailed form and function of the brain=
 (eg topology and connection<br>
> strengths). <br>
<br></div>
I agree w=
ith you. It also means that the very same network region can show different=
 behavior depending on the input it receives (e.g. visual cortices can be i=
nvolved in auditory task when no retinal input drives the system). For comp=
utational studies this means, we should seek for networks that are able to =
adapt to different types of input.<div class=3D"im">
<br>
<br>
> It seem=
s more like natural genomes encode the neuron and<br>
> synapse types, a=
nd which regions of the brain they go in, and the<br>
> properties of th=
ese neuron and synapse types. <br>
<br></div>
That's why I developed th=
e "Brain in a box" model, a naive approach, in which a CPPN just =
encodes the position and orientation of dendritic and axonal projection con=
es. Intersections of cones lead to connections between neurons. But there a=
re better ways to implement this.<div class=3D"im">
<br>
<br>
>I suspect=
 there are still<br>
> some regions where the genome encodes, one way or=
 another, a fairly precise<br>
> topology (though even in this case the =
genome could make use of how the<br>
> neurons and synapses self-organis=
e).<br>
<br></div>
you mean, like in c. elegans, which has exactly 302 neur=
ons.!? I am wondering, whether it is correct to say that in simpler organis=
ms natural encodings tend to encode the precise topology whereas with incre=
asing complexity the encoding leaves more organizational tasks to self-orga=
nizing mechanisms.<div class=3D"im">
<br>
<br>
> <br>
> As part of my=
 current work I'm planning on reproducing many of these<br>
> proper=
ties, including synaptic transmission delays, in a neural network<br>
> =
model to see how they affect the evolvability and capabilities of evolved<b=
r>
> networks performing online learning. I'm planning on using Hype=
rNEAT or a<br>
> variant like ES-HyperNEAT, and am in the middle of impl=
ementing these kinds<br>
> of properties in a neural network model and c=
reating a flexible HyperNEAT<br>
> set-up to allow specifying the parame=
ters for models of these properties.<br>
> The motivation being that a l=
ot of these properties have been implicated in<br>
> learning processes =
in the brain. See <a href=3D"http://ojcoleman.com/node/1" target=3D"_blank"=
>http://ojcoleman.com/node/1</a> and<br>
> <a href=3D"http://ojcoleman.c=
om/node/3" target=3D"_blank">http://ojcoleman.com/node/3</a> for details an=
d links to the software. ;)<br>
<br></div>
Thanks for the links (btw: I com=
mented in your third posting ;)). But I did not find any link to the softwa=
re you use? Do you work in Matlab, Python or something else?<br>
<br>
With =
a colleague, we work on a model that implements structural plasticity, hete=
rogeneous conduction delays and STDP in spiking neurons (we use the Izhikev=
ich neuron and everything is implemented in Matlab). Synapses are build dep=
ending on the activation level of the neuron and its projection kernel. I t=
hink, the projection kernel could be something that can be encoded by a CPP=
N. Having this kind of super-gun, we are now facing the question: how to se=
tup an appropriate fitness-function, which runs a bit into the discussions =
we had here the last weeks. :-)<br>

<br>
Best,<br>
Martin<br>
<br>
<p></p>=
